item.title: Syllabus
item.description: When & Where Mondays and Wednesdays | 2:30pm | Thomas 120 Instructor Anton Nekrutenko aun1@psu.edu Wartik 505 Office hours by appointment only IMPORTANT: When contacting instructor use the above e-mail and include “BMMB554” in the subject line (you can simply click on e-mail address above as Subject already filled in there).

item.title: Finding DNA/Protein interactions
item.description: An overview of ChIP seq This material is based on a variety of sources acknowledged throughout this document. It follows the logic of a comprehensive overview of ChIP-seq methodology compiled by Shaun Mahony at Penn State.

item.title: Writing
item.description: Writing is hard! Writing simply is harder! But there are great resources! Below are links to one such resource: The Title Says It All The Abstract and the Elevator Talk: A Tale of Two Summaries “It was a cold and rainy night”: Set the Scene with a Good Introduction Who, What, When, Where, How, and Why: The Ingredients in the Recipe for a Successful Methods Section Show Your Cards: The Results Section and the Poker Game If an IRDAM Journal Is What You Choose, Then Sequential Results Are What You Use Put Your Best Figure Forward: Line Graphs and Scattergrams Bars and Pies Make Better Desserts than Figures (also see this) Bring Your Best to the Table The Discussion Section: Your Closing Argument Giving Credit: Citations and References How to Write a Rave Review Top 10 Tips for Responding to Reviewer and Editor Comments Passing the Paternité Test (also see this) Also see:

item.title: Reference-based RNA-seq
item.description: RNAseq: Reference-based This tutorial is inspired by an exceptional RNAseq course at the Weill Cornell Medical College compiled by Friederike Dündar, Luce Skrabanek, and Paul Zumbo and by tutorials produced by Björn Grüning (@bgruening) for Freiburg Galaxy instance.

item.title: Diploid variant calling
item.description: Today we hear a lot about personalized medicine. Yet the personalization is defined by the genetic make up of the individual. Today we will discuss how this information can be uncovered from the genomic sequencing data.

item.title: First analysis
item.description: Our first actual analysis Trajectories for the four teams in this class: Team 1 Team 2 Team 3 Team 4 10.

item.title: Diving into analyses
item.description: Setting up Jupyter For our analyses we will be using Jupyter. The problem is that everyone in this class has a different computer setup, which may cause issues with running Jupyter.

item.title: Variant calling: Pooled and Haploid systems
item.description: The majority of life on Earth is non-diploid and represented by prokaryotes, viruses and their derivatives such as our own mitochondria or plant’s chloroplasts. In non-diploid systems allele frequencies can range anywhere between 0 and 100% and there could be multiple (not just two) alleles per locus.

item.title: NGS data: Practicalities
item.description: In this section we will look at practical aspects of manipulation of next-generation sequencing data. We will start with Fastq format produced by most sequencing machines and will finish with SAM/BAM format representing mapped reads.

item.title: Python: The very first try
item.description: Today we will have an introduction to Python - a general purpose programming language. We will do this by relying on two great resources: Software Carpentry Jupyter Setting up you screen Open the following browser windows:

item.title: Aligning many sequences quickly
item.description: Speeding things up The topics we discussed in the past lecture explain fundamental concepts behind analysis of biological sequences. Today, we will be talking about algorithms that allow aligning billions of sequencing reads against reference genomes.

item.title: Sequence alignment: Introductory concepts
item.description: The cover image shows pairwise alignments for human, mouse, and dog KIF3 locus from Dubchak et al. 2000. Introduction to dynamic programming (Based on dynamic programming example from InteractivePython).

item.title: Assembly basics
item.description: Genome assembly is a difficult task. In trying to explain it I will be relying on two highly regarded sources: Ben Langmead’s Teaching Materials Pevzner and Compeau Bioinformatics Book.

item.title: DNA Sequencing: PabBio, ONT and others
item.description: PacBio Single Molecule Sequencing PacBio is a fundamentally different approach to DNA sequencing as it allows reading single molecules. Thus it is an example is so called Single Molecule Sequencing or SMS.

item.title: DNA Sequencing: Illumina
item.description: A few classical papers to start In a series of now classical papersp Philip Green and co-workers has developed a quantitative framework for the analysis of data generated by automated DNA sequencers.

item.title: DNA Sequencing: From Sanger to 454
item.description: The 50s, 60s and the 70s The difficulty with sequencing nucleic acids is nicely summarized by Hutchinson:2007: The chemical properties of different DNA molecules were so similar that it appeared difficult to separate them.

item.title: History
item.description: Why history? Knowing history is essential for understanding how we arrived to the current state of affairs in our field. It is also full of accidental discoveries and dramatic relationships making it quite interesting to read about.
